texts.shortText: Forms bushy clumps or extensive carpets firmly anchored to the rock, or to limpet shells. Clumps formed of numerous short, densely-packed, pink to purple axes, often faded towards the exposed tips. The axes are upright and vary from almost cylindrical to distinctly flattened, segments short and often with pyramid-shaped or pentagonal outline. Axes branch repeatedly forming broad ‘fronds’. Reproductive conceptacles club-shaped and white, borne at the ends of the branches.
Axes typically up to about 50 mm tall. Clumps typically about 50 mm across, but can be extensive, covering areas 200 mm or more across.

Global: Widely distributed in temperate seas including Europe, USA, Argentina, South Africa, China, Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula eastwards.

Common and abundant, forming dense clumps in low-shore pools and on subtidal rocks. The taxonomic position of the South African specimens is uncertain and recent genetic studies have shown that they are not the same as the European C. officinalis, so need to be either reclassified or described as new species. As this has not yet been done though, we retain the currently used name.
Conceptacles appear as rounded chalky white nodules on the terminal segments of axes.

Specimens classified under this name seem to vary variable and several species may in fact be involved. The repeatedly branching axes and rounded terminal conceptacles as fairly good identification features though.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 416).

Kogame, K, Uwai, S, Anderson, RJ, Choi, H-G & Bolton, JJ (2017). DNA barcoding of South African geniculate coralline red algae (Corallinales, Rhodophyta). South African Journal of Botany, 108, 337-341.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 584).

Williamson, CJ, Walker, RH, Robba, L, Yesson, C, Russell, S, Irvine, LM & Brodie J (2015). Toward resolution of species diversity and distribution in the calcified red algal genera Corallina and Ellisolandia (Corallinales, Rhodophyta). Phycologia 54: 2-11.
